Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Seismic Performance of Reinforced Concrete Buildings with Shear Walls
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will closely analyze structural deficiencies that lead to total collapse and non-repairable damage of reinforced concrete buildings due to earthquakes. There will be specific concentration on buildings that have or can benefit from using shear walls. The main focus of this project is to study in detail the series of failures that lead to total loss, and to evaluate the economic benefits of adding shear walls. Research will be conducted at GNS Science located in Lower Hutt, under the mentorship of Dr. S.R. Uma, a renowned expert in the field of earthquake engineering and structural response. In depth engineering reports will be made available that focus on structural failure details from the 2010 and 2011 Christchurch earthquakes. The outcomes of this project will lead to improved recognition of dangerous buildings, improved accuracy of computer modeling, and greater understanding of the economic benefits of retrofitting dangerous structures. New Zealand is an optimal location to study seismic performance because of the Christchurch earthquakes which destroyed many structures and because of the detailed engineering reports that have been produced since.

This project will help develop nonlinear structural analysis skill and technique to accurately simulate localized failures in concrete structures. Nonlinear computer simulation of structures is a still-developing tool for engineers to study how a building behaves as a whole under dynamic loading. In the United States, nonlinear modeling techniques are being used to evaluate the seismic risk of structures that were built before modern buildings codes and structural analysis tools. Even with recent advances in nonlinear modeling techniques, it is difficult to accurately simulate the total collapse of buildings like the Pyne Gould building in Christchurch which killed 182 people in 2011, because of the multitude of smaller local failures that lead to the global collapse. Understanding the deficiencies of concrete structures and taking steps to retrofit them must allow for, at a minimum, life-safety of building occupants, minimal loss of building functionality, and economic viability. By improving understanding of retrofit options and trade-offs, this project will inform decision-making about the identification and improvement of dangerous RC shear wall structures in the U.S. and around the world. This award is funded in collaboration with the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research funded by this NSF grant investigated the seismic performance of wall-frame (dual system) reinforced concrete structures in Christchurch, New Zealand. Dual system structures are of particular interest because of many high profile building collapses around the world. Before the 2010-2011 earthquakes around Christchurch the building infrastructure comprised mostly of reinforced concrete buildings. The major seismic event that happened in February of 2011 produced ground accelerations that were in excess of design accelerations considered in the structural design of many of these buildings. The advantage that this offers to this research is that we are able to look closely at the nonlinear behavior of multiple structures of seeming similar construct in effort to identify specific characteristics that can be used to identify other buildings that may be dangerous to human life.

 To achieve this task access to a database containing detailed engineering damage reports was granted by host researcher Dr. S.R. Uma at the office of GNS Science in Lower Hutt, New Zealand. The first half of the allowed research time was spent studying these reports and selecting a pool of buildings that would be used as potential case studies. The case studies had to meet certain criteria such as being a reinforced concrete wall-frame structure, had to be designed before 1985, and had to experience some level of damage that was well documented.

Damage reports of the buildings needed to be linked to the specific details of the building design. In order to achieve that task then the building plans for each of the case studies needed to be obtained from the Christchurch City Council. Many of the case studies were older buildings and a readable set of building plans was not always available. Moreover, the building plans were stored in a storage facility near Christchurch that required special access. The property files were made accessible and building plans could also be scanned but each for a cost that was out of the scope of the awarded grant money. Therefore, the number of total case studies had to be narrowed to nine final case studies which turned out to be a strong foundation for the remaining of the research conducted in New Zealand.

In addition to the two previous tasks, an exhaustive list of critical structural weaknesses that could be easily observed from a set of old building plans was comprised through reference to various sources including Royal Commissions reports, Peer reviewed journal articles, and student dissertations from the University of Canterbury. Critical structural weaknesses are building characteristics such as non-symmetric wall layouts, soft stories, weak stories, shear critical columns, short columns, transfer beams, etc. Identifying and quantifying the critical structural weaknesses inherent to each specific case study building turned out to be the metric for identifying dangerous buildings this research hoped to achieve.

The most meaningful finding from this research directly relates the severity of building damage to the quantity of critical structural weaknesses inherent to building composition. The finding is that probability of collapse is directly proportionally to the quantity of critical weaknesses in a particular structure despite the exact nature or specific combination of critical structural weaknesses. Further research, which is based on these findings, will focus on the interaction of various critical structural weaknesses. One of the case study buildings from Christchurch is being used to develop large scale three dimensional models that will be used simulate a buildings seismic performance. Modern super computing capabilities allow us to model large complex systems and look closer at problems like this that was not possible just 10 years ago. Among the desired outcomes from this project will be to determine if simply identifying the quantity of critical structural weaknesses in older structures is a robust enough method to accurately predict the risk of collapse for a building and or identify and single out the structures that pose the highest risk of collapse.
